title: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf | Academy of Achievement

quotes: In 2003, the disgraced president fled to Nigeria.

In 2005, President George W. Bush presents the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor, to the President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, in an awards ceremony in the East Room of the White House.
In 2005, Johnson Sirleaf resigned from the Commission to accept the nomination of the Unity Party as its candidate for President of Liberia in the country’s first truly free election.
On January 16, 2006, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf was sworn in as the 24th President of Liberia.
Johnson Sirleaf spent the next five years repairing the damage done by 25 years of violence and misrule.

organizations.name: Kormah Development and Investment Corporation
quotes: she established a venture capital firm, the Kormah Development and Investment Corporation, as well as Measuagoon, a community development NGO for Liberia.

organizations.name: Measuagoon
quotes: she established a venture capital firm, the Kormah Development and Investment Corporation, as well as Measuagoon, a community development NGO for Liberia.

organizations.name: Governance Reform Commission of the Transitional Government
quotes: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf returned to Liberia in 2003 to chair the Governance Reform Commission of the Transitional Government.

organizations.name: General Auditing Commission
quotes: she successfully transferred the reporting mechanism of the General Auditing Commission from the control of the executive branch to the legislature, enabling more democratic oversight of the nation’s finances.

organizations.name: Unity Party
quotes: In 2005, Johnson Sirleaf resigned from the Commission to accept the nomination of the Unity Party as its candidate for President of Liberia in the country’s first truly free election.

organizations.name: International Criminal Court
quotes: The International Criminal Court sentenced Taylor, age 64, to 50 years in prison.

organizations.name: Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace
quotes: pressure from the international community — and the courageous nonviolent resistance of the Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace — eventually led to Taylor’s resignation.

roles.title: President of Liberia
quotes: The new President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, dons the presidential sash with assistance from Liberia’s Senior Ambassador-at-Large, George W. Wallace, Jr., during her inauguration ceremony at the Capitol Building in Monrovia, Liberia, January 16, 2006.

quotes: The new President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, dons the presidential sash with assistance from Liberia’s Senior Ambassador-at-Large, George W. Wallace, Jr., during her inauguration ceremony at the Capitol Building in Monrovia, Liberia, January 16, 2006.

roles.title: Africa’s first elected female head of state
quotes: Johnson Sirleaf was Africa’s first elected female head of state.

roles.title: first elected female head of state in African history
quotes: She is the first elected female head of state in African history.

When President Taylor threatened to have her killed for her opposition to his administration, she moved to the neighboring country of Côte d’Ivoire, where she established a venture capital firm, the Kormah Development and Investment Corporation, as well as Measuagoon, a community development NGO for Liberia.
a community development NGO for Liberia.

The new President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, dons the presidential sash with assistance from Liberia’s Senior Ambassador-at-Large, George W. Wallace, Jr., during her inauguration ceremony at the Capitol Building in Monrovia, Liberia, January 16, 2006.
In 2003, the disgraced president fled to Nigeria.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf returned to Liberia in 2003 to chair the Governance Reform Commission of the Transitional Government.

2005: President George W. Bush presents the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor, to the President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, in an awards ceremony in the East Room of the White House. (AP)
